{{short description|Favoritism granted to relatives or friends}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2021}} [[File:Benjamin Harrison Astley Cooper.jpg|thumb|right|[[Benjamin Harrison (hospital administrator)|Benjamin Harrison]], treasurer of [[Guy's Hospital]] in London, was shown as a dominant presiding figure, with the nepotism of [[Astley Cooper|Sir Astley Cooper]] having his tacit approval.]] {{Political corruption sidebar}} {{Discrimination sidebar|expand-social=yes}} '''Nepotism''' is the act of granting an [[In-group favoritism|advantage]], privilege, or position to [[Kinship|relatives]] or friends in an occupation or field - for instance business, politics, academia, entertainment, religion or [[health care]]. In concept it is similar to [[cronyism]].{{cite encyclopedia |entry-url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/nepotism |entry=nepotism |dictionary=Cambridge Dictionary |access-date=23 July 2021 |title=NEPOTISM | meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary |archive-date=12 November 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112042128/https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/nepotism |url-status=live }}{{cite encyclopedia |entry-url=https://www.dictionary.com/browse/nepotism |entry=nepotism | title=Dictionary.com |access-date=23 July 2021 |archive-date=16 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210516040552/https://www.dictionary.com/browse/nepotism |url-status=live }} The term originated with the assignment of nephews, sons, or other relatives to important positions by Catholic popes and bishops.{{cite web |url=http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224025607/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archive-date=24 February 2007 |website=New Catholic Dictionary |title=nepotism}} It has often been witnessed in [[Autocracy|autocracies]], whereby [[Aristocracy|traditional aristocracies]] usually contested amongst themselves in order to obtain leverage, status, etc. Nepotism has been criticized since [[ancient history]] by philosophers including [[Aristotle]], [[Thiruvalluvar|Valluvar]], and [[Confucius]], condemning it as both evil and unwise.{{cite book | last = Sundaram | first = P. S. | title = Tiruvalluvar: The Kural | publisher = Penguin Books | edition = First | date = 1990 | location = Gurgaon | pages = 12 | isbn = 978-0-14-400009-8 }} == Origins == {{Main|Cardinal-nephew}} The term comes from Italian word ''nepotismo'',[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/nepotism "Nepotism."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160125235043/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/nepotism |date=25 January 2016 }} Dictionary.com. Retrieved 20 June 2013.{{cite web |title=In Praise of Nepotism: A Natural History |work=[[Adam Bellow]] Booknotes interview transcript |url=http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926013727/http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archive-date=26 September 2010 |access-date=10 September 2013}} which is based on Latin root ''nepos'' meaning nephew.{{cite web |title=Article nepos |work=CTCWeb Glossary |url=http://www.ablemedia.com/ctcweb/glossary/glossaryn.html#nepos |access-date=10 September 2013 |archive-date=8 April 2000 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000408143615/http://www.ablemedia.com/ctcweb/glossary/glossaryn.html#nepos |url-status=live }} Since the [[Middle Ages]] and until the late 17th century, some [[Catholicism|Catholic]] popes and bishops – who had taken vows of [[chastity]] and, therefore, usually had no legitimate offspring of their own – gave their nephews such positions of preference as were often accorded by fathers to sons.{{cite web|title=Article Nepotism |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://catholic-forum.com/saints/ncd05726.htm |access-date=12 July 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224025607/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archive-date=24 February 2007 }} They would also do the same with children who were the illegitimate result of broken celibacy vows, and who were claimed to be "nephews" instead of sons.{{cite web|title=Papal Crimes|work=Church and State|date=9 February 2024 |url=https://churchandstate.org.uk/2024/02/the-papal-crimes-that-reveal-medieval-vatican/|access-date=5 September 2024}} Several popes [[Cardinal-nephew|elevated nephews]] and other relatives to the [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinalate]]. Often, such appointments were a means of continuing a papal "dynasty".{{cite book|author1=Gianvittorio Signorotto|author2=Maria Antonietta Visceglia|title=Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492–1700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2W1tc-wf5DQC&pg=PA114|access-date=20 June 2013|date=21 March 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-43141-5|pages=114–116}} For instance, [[Pope Callixtus III]], head of the [[House of Borgia|Borgia]] family, made two of his nephews cardinals; one of them, Rodrigo, later used his position as a cardinal as a stepping stone to the papacy, becoming [[Pope Alexander VI]].{{cite web |title=Article Pope Alexander VI |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01289a.htm |access-date=12 July 2007 |archive-date=1 May 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501192839/http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01289a.htm |url-status=live }} Alexander then elevated Alessandro Farnese, his mistress's brother, to cardinal; Farnese would later go on to become [[Pope Paul III]].{{cite encyclopedia |title=Article Pope Paul III |encyclopedia=Catholic Encyclopedia |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11579a.htm |access-date=12 July 2007 |archive-date=1 May 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501215904/http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11579a.htm |url-status=live }} Paul III also engaged in nepotism, appointing, for instance, two nephews, aged 14 and 16, as cardinals. The practice was finally limited when [[Pope Innocent XII]] issued the [[Papal bull|bull]] ''[[Romanum decet Pontificem]]'', in 1692. The papal bull prohibited popes in all times from bestowing estates, offices, or revenues on any relative, with the exception that one qualified relative (at most) could be made a cardinal.{{cite book|author=Anura Gurugé|title=The Next Pope|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B5JVthemvvwC&pg=PA115|access-date=20 June 2013|date=16 February 2010|publisher=Anura Guruge|isbn=978-0-615-35372-2|page=115}} ===Mention in ancient literature=== In the [[Book of Porul|second book]] of the [[Tirukkural|Kural literature]], which forms a manual for governments and corporations, [[Valluvar]] suggests about nepotism and favouritism thus:
If you choose an unfit person for your job just because you love and you like him, he will lead you to endless follies.{{Cite web |url=https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/rediscovering-a-management-and-leadership-manual-in-ancient-indian-literature/ |title=Rediscovering a Management and Leadership Manual in Ancient Indian Literature – Knowledge@Wharton |access-date=4 February 2023 |archive-date=17 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221117054622/https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/rediscovering-a-management-and-leadership-manual-in-ancient-indian-literature/ |url-status=live }}
According to him, nepotism is both evil and unwise. == Types == === Political === Nepotism is a common accusation in politics when the relative of a powerful figure ascends to similar power seemingly without appropriate qualifications. The [[British English]] expression "[[Bob's your uncle]]" is thought to have originated when [[Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury]], promoted his nephew, [[Arthur Balfour]], to the esteemed post of [[Chief Secretary for Ireland]], which was widely seen as an act of nepotism.[https://books.google.com/books?id=K0zrsHO27-wC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72 ''From Aristotelian to Reaganomics: A Dictionary of Eponyms With Biographies in the Social Science''], by R. C. S. Trahair, [[Greenwood Publishing Group]], 1994, p. 72. Retrieved online from [[Google Books]], 30 July 2012. ===Economic=== [[Inheritance]] has been viewed by some as a form of nepotism.{{cite journal | last=Pérez-González | first=Francisco | title=Inherited Control and Firm Performance | journal=American Economic Review | volume=96 | issue=5 | date=1 November 2006 | issn=0002-8282 | doi=10.1257/aer.96.5.1559 | pages=1559–1588}} === Organizational === Nepotism in organizations leads to [[monopolization]] of power because when members involved in institutional [[decision-making]] are related, decisions made within institutions risk favoring a group of closely connected people.{{Cite journal |last1=Teixeira da Silva |first1=Jaime A. |last2=Katavić |first2=Vedran |last3=Dobránszki |first3=Judit |last4=Al-Khatib |first4=Aceil |archive-date=17 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221217020813/http://komejournal.com/files/KOME_MS_rulesethicists.pdf |url-status=live }} Nepotism can also occur within as unethical, both on the part of the employer and employee."Richard Utz, "Beyond Consanguinity," ''[https://www.insidehighered.com/advice/2010/03/24/beyond-consanguinity Inside Higher Ed] One of the consequences of nepotism in an organization is the creation of a limitation in the organization's network of contacts, reducing the opportunities for negotiation with other social circles, which can lead to a reduction in the success and duration of organizations in the long term.{{Cite book |title=The handbook of business and corruption: cross-sectoral experiences |date=2017 |editor=Michael S. Aßländer |editor2=Sarah Hudson |isbn=978-1-78635-445-7 |location=Bingley, UK |oclc=1003263368}} ==== In employment ==== Nepotism at work can mean increased opportunity at a job, attaining a job or being paid more than other similarly situated people.{{cite web |url=http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/nepotismatwork.html |title=Nepotism at Work |publisher=Safeworkers.co.uk |date=20 April 2013 |access-date=20 June 2013 |archive-date=4 April 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190404005247/http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/NepotismAtWork.html |url-status=live }} Arguments are made both for and against employment granted due to a family connection, which is most common in small, [[family business|family run businesses]]. On one hand, nepotism can provide stability and continuity. Critics cite studies that demonstrate decreased morale and commitment from non-related employees,{{cite web |url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=1625 |title=Family Ties: Handling Nepotism Within Your Business – Perspectives – Inside INdiana Business with Gerry Dick |publisher=Insideindianabusiness.com |date=9 November 2010 |access-date=20 June 2013 |archive-date=14 May 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514022519/http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=1625 |url-status=live }} and a generally negative attitude towards superior positions filled through nepotism. An article from ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine stated "there is no ladder to climb when the top rung is reserved for people with a certain name."{{cite news |url=http://www.forbes.com/2009/06/19/ceo-executive-hiring-ceonewtork-leadership-nepotism.html |title=Is Nepotism So Bad? |work=Forbes |access-date=20 June 2013 |first=Klaus |last=Kneale |archive-date=9 October 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191009125614/https://www.forbes.com/2009/06/19/ceo-executive-hiring-ceonewtork-leadership-nepotism.html |url-status=live }} Employing intimate people favors perpetuating the ideas or goals of those who employ them, knowing that the people around them will face up to them. However, it can lead to a lack of competent staff or a reduction in [[productivity]] because even if the employees are not the best options for their functions, they will be protected by those who employ them.{{Cite journal |last=Safina |first=Dinara |date=2015 |title=Favouritism and Nepotism in an Organization: Causes and Effects |journal=Procedia Economics and Finance |language=en |volume=23 |pages=630–634 |doi=10.1016/S2212-5671(15)00416-5 |doi-access=free }} Some businesses forbid nepotism as an ethical matter, considering it too troublesome and disruptive. Most Companies' Codes of Conduct include severe disciplinary sanction for [[Conflicts of Interest]]. ===Indonesia=== [[Suharto]], Indonesia's second president, is involved in nepotism, alongside corruption and [[collusion]] (together, they are known as the ''KKN'' in {{langx|id|korupsi, kolusi, dan nepotisme}}). Companies belonging to Suharto's children, particularly Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana ("Tutut"), Hutomo Mandala Putra ("Tommy"), and Bambang Trihatmodjo, were given lucrative government contracts and protected from market competition by monopolies. Examples include the toll-expressway company [[:id:Jasamarga|Jasamarga]] (monopolized by Tutut), the national car project [[Timor]] (monopolized by Bambang and Tommy), and the cinema market (monopolized by [[:id:21 Cineplex|21 Cineplex]], which is owned by Suharto's cousin Sudwikatmono). The family is said to control about {{Cvt|36000|km2}} of real estate in Indonesia, including {{Cvt|100000|m2}} of prime office space in Jakarta and nearly 40% of the land in [[East Timor]]. Since the [[1948 Mauritian general election|first democratic elections in 1948]], the field of politics in Mauritius has been marked by a handful of families who have controlled the four major political parties which exist to this day. They are often referred to as the "modern dynasties" of Mauritian politics such as the Duval, Bérenger, Curé, Uteem, Mohamed, Boolell, Ramgoolam and Jugnauth families.
